msDesc.head: Vacarius, Liberpauperum (frag.), Justinian, Codex, with the gloss of Accursius

physDesc.p: Fore- and endleaves: fols.ir-iiv, Vr-VIv, text, = 1; fol. iiir, bookplates; fols. iiiv-ivr notes, pentrials; fols. ivv-vv, text, = 2; fol. virv, notes on civil law; fols. VIIr-VIIIv, fragments of printed flyleaves.

extent.measure: 280 membrane leaves, preceded by six medieval membrane leaves and followed by two paper flyleaves (fols. I-II) and their stubs (fols. III-IV), pages of an incunable (see Binding).

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.

msItem.incipit: Si quo magis to de ui hostium Fol. iiv, upper half.
msItem.explicit: Hec autem omnia in hiis a nobis cauta sunt quibus Fol. iiv, lower half.
msItem.author: Vacarius
msItem.title: Liber pauperum (frag.)

note.p: 2.16-26, ed. F. de Zulueta, The Liber pauperum of Vacarius (Selden Soc. 44, 1927). For the tituli see also H. van de Wouw, Brocardica Dunelmensia, Zeitschrift der Savigny-Stiflung fur Rechtsgeschichte: Romanistische Abteilung, 108 (1991), 234-78.

The text runs from Vacarius 2.16 (Digest,IV-i. 9, 1) to Vacarius 2.26 (Codex, III-i. 13, 10), the first and last tituli incomplete. There is a gap of one sheet, the centre bifolium of the quire, containing text from Vacarius 2.26 (c. Codex, II-xl. 5) to Vacarius 2.39 (Digest, IV-viii. 32). Fol. VI, the remains of another leaf, containing ten to twelve lines from the top of one half-sheet, has on its recto Vacarius 2.32, Digest, IV-ii. 23, 4, which shows that this is not part of the missing centre of the quire.
For fuller details (but not taking account of fol. VI) see F. de Zulueta, The All Souls Fragments of Vacarius, BQR 3 (1921), 164-5, but note that since his time the leaves have been renumbered.
On Vacarius see de Zulueta, edn., introduction, and on this text also J. L. Barton, The Study of Civil Law before 1380, HUO i. 519-30, at 519, 523-5, and references

support.p: Fols. i-ii, V, VI are three sheets and a small fragment of a sheet laid sideways with tops or bottoms of pages in the gutter, i.e. 6 fols. = 12 pages, all (except VI?) part of one quire of an early 13th-century manuscript. The correct order of pages is as follows (ru indicating, as now bound, the upper page of a recto leaf, rl its lower page, vu the upper page of a verso leaf, and vl its lower page): fol. iivu, iiru, ivu, iru, Vru, Vvu, Vvl, Vrl, irl, ivl, iirl, iivl.
Written on average-quality membrane on sheets that were probably c. 340 × 240 mm in size, folded HSOS (HFFH).

layout.p: The layout is in two columns for Corpus juris, each 168 x 45 mm, c.50 lines, with columns of gloss to left and right. A fifth column towards the outer edge of the page contains Vacarius, and a sixth, almost entirely trimmed away, has more glosses. Surviving Vacarius glosses begin in the upper margins and continue where necessary into the lower margins.
Pricked in inner and outer margins, and ruled in hardpoint.

handDesc.handNote: Written in a small gothic bookhand, above top line; the Vacarius and the other glosses in various glossing hands

decoDesc.decoNote: Simple red and blue one-line lombards but on fol. ir a six-line lombard and on fol. iir two- and five-line lombards with marginal flourishing.
Rubrics are in alternating red and blue lombards and there are red and blue paraphs and red linefillers.

origin.p: De Zulueta notes that the fragments are very similar to the Vacarius in Avranches, Bibl. mun., MS 142, in the scripts of both the main text and of the glosses, in illumination [sic, but there is none; he presumably meant decoration], rubrication, the colour of initials, and the organization of the page, and he suggests that they may, like the Avranches manuscript, come from Mont Saint-Michel. As they bear no signs of English use they probably reached England as binding fragments.

note.p: The tituli of the Codex. Fol. ivv, an added leaf which probably replaces a lost or damaged leaf, is in an English hand of s. xiv, listing the tituli as far as VI-V (to which VII is then added in another English hand). The tituli then continue on Fol. vrv in an Italian hand, with notes in anglicana, s. xiv.

msItem.rubric: In nomine domini nostri ihesu christi codicis domini iustiniani sanctissimi principis perpetui augusti repetite prelectionis hec incipiunt constituciones de nouo codice faciendo. rubrica unum. fol. 1r
msItem.incipit: Hec que necessario corrigenda esse fol. 1r
msItem.explicit: Quisquis crimen intendit non impu fol. 279v
msItem.incipit: In nomine domini incipit a domino ut super consueuit fol. 1r
msItem.explicit: si putant dampnum esse si res illas conferant fol. 280v
msItem.author: Justinian, I, Emperor of the East, 483?–565
msItem.title: Codex

note.p: Justinian, Codex, I-i.1 to IX-xlvi.10 with the gloss of Accursius and other marginal glosses. Text ed. Krueger, CICii. 1-391. For early editions see Hain 9597-621. For the gloss, early editions, and sources on Accursius see MS 49, item 4. Because of the loss of leaf 7 in quire 18, fol. 210v ends si fraudem (VII-viii.5) and resumes on fol. 211r necessarium et venire (VI-xii.2). The text breaks off in IX-xlvi.10 and the fragmentary fol. 280 contains no more. The accompanying gloss ends in IX-xlvi, resumes for a few lines on fol. 280r, and finally ceases as above in the gloss on IX-xlix.8, the lex, Si deportatus. There are extra glosses in hands of s. xiv.

supportDesc.support: Written on 280 leaves (280 is a fragment) of average-quality membrane, prepared in the Italian manner, but not well, with hair and flesh sides very similar. Folded FSOS (FHHF).

collation.catchwords: Catchwords or traces of them survive on fols. 12v, 24v, 96v, 144v, 168v, all written by the scribe of the main text except that on fol. 24v which is in anglicana.
collation.signatures: Several systems of quire numbers and signatures partly survive. The first two quires of 3 have lowercase roman figures on versos but the third quire has them on rectos. On other rectos are traces of two further series, (1) one to six vertical strokes, and (2) on quire 15, o, oo, [ooo], oooo, ov, oiv (o being a symbol and not letter o). In the bottom margin of fols. 13r, 14r, 114r, 133r, 157r, >169r, 181r, 220r, and 249r are the remains of a more elaborate system of quire-numbering, in a cursive English hand probably of s. xiv. A typical example (fol. 169r) is 1 fo. xv quaterni but on fols. 114r and 220r the numbered leaves are the sixth and fifth leaves of the tenth and nineteenth quaterni respectively.

layoutDesc.layout: 3, the central area of text, written in two columns each 60 mm wide, 73-6 lines, is of variable height. The gloss, written on all sides of it, has c. 110 lines on a full page.
*2 is in three columns, each 330 x c.50 mm, 73-6 lines. Margins are trimmed and the only prickings visible are those for vertical rulings. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: *2, the tituli, are in anglicana and gothic rotunda bookhand
Fol. ivv is in an English hand of s. xiv, with additions in another English hand.
Fol. vrv in an Italian hand, with notes in anglicana, s. xiv.

3, the main text and gloss, were written by a scribe trained in Italy (Bologna?) who was probably working in a French centre in the early 14th century, using an Italian gothic rotunda bookhand, single-compartment a in the gloss as distinct from double-compartment a in the text being the only real difference apart from size. Two lines of Accursian gloss are written for one line of text.

The script of the small gloss is a very cursive anglicana by more than one hand. On fol. 58v a rubric has been written over an erased gloss, showing that at least some rubrication followed glossing. As in MSS 51 and 52 the several scribes wrote nonsense or series of minims or arbitrary letters to bring columns of the gloss to full length. Punctuation is by medial and low point and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Alexander and Temple, no. 299 (pl. xxr, no. 299, repr. detail of fol. 129r, reduced; fol. 158" repr. in our Pl. 4). Pace Dolezalek, ii, the series of fine historiated miniatures is intact: they are: fol. Tr, prologue, Imperator ad Senatum', Justinian enthroned before three standing men two of whom are tonsured; fol. 2", bk. I, De summa trinitate etfide catholica, God the Father; fol. 36', bk. II, De edendo, Justinian enthroned before four standing men, of whom two (three?) are tonsured; fol. 58', bk. III, De iudiciis, Justinian enthroned before two lictors(?) carrying staves over left shoulders; fol. 83", bk. iv, De rebus creditis et de iureiurando, Justinian enthroned, with a book on his knees, a kneeling man swearing an oath with his hand on the book and another man standing by; fol. 123`, bk. v, De sponsalibus, a man taking a woman as his wife, a second female figure standing by; fol. 158", bk. VI, De fitgitiuis semis, Justinian enthroned, two figures before him, one lacking footwear and brandishing an axe, the other standing by; fol. 206r, bk. VII, De uindicta libertate, Justinian enthroned, with a man kneeling before him whom he touches on the shoulder with a sword, with another man standing by holding a rolled-up scroll. At the beginning of bks. VIII and ix there are no miniatures, only illuminated initials. Although the script shows that the book was written by a continental scribe, the decoration is English, apart from a majority of the lombards. Dr M. A. Michael identifies the artist as one artist of the Holkham Secretum (BL, MS Add. 47680), Hereford Cathedral Library MS O. vitt. 7 and other books associated with the Oxfordpecia system. He further identifies Vienna, Nationalbibliothek, MS 2262 as being partly decorated by the same artist (after being written on the Continent by an Italian-trained scribe) who also worked on the Walter of Milemete manuscript now Oxford, Christ Church, MS 92. The Vienna manuscript contains Codex bks. x—xit and although it is uncertain that it and our manuscript were designed as a pair (the glossing apparatus to the main text is by different hands) it bears a 1333 cautio by the Oxford Master Johannes de Hudicote (BRUO) which helps to confirm the approximate date of the artist's work in Oxford. On these Oxford-decorated manuscripts see M. A. Michael, `Oxford, Cambridge and London: Towards a Theory for `Grouping' Gothic Manuscripts', Burlington Magazine, 13o (1988), 107-15. By the time our manuscript reached Oxford it had received Italian-style display capitals, blue lombards flourished red and plain two-line red initials, running titles in red-and-blue (guided by crayon numbers) and red and blue paraphs. In England blue and red lombards flourished mauve were added, and rubrics which match the red of the English lombards but not the red of the small Italian initials. The gloss has Italian-style red and blue initials and paraphs and some English lombards.
